recommendations: Select a dedicated 'CT Thoracic Aorta CTA' protocol with arterial phase timing optimized for aortic opacification (approximately 20-30 seconds post-injection).
Administer a cautious pre-contrast isotonic fluid bolus (250-500 mL) with continuous hemodynamic monitoring, and consider vasoactive support if MAP remains below 55 mmHg.
Utilize a low-osmolar or iso-osmolar non-ionic contrast agent at a reduced volume (e.g., 80 mL).
Schedule post-contrast serum creatinine and eGFR checks at 12-24 hours and 24-48 hours post-administration.
rationale: The primary diagnosis of 'Injury to thoracic aorta' necessitates a protocol specifically designed for thoracic aorta visualization.
Severe hypotension (MAP 49.3 mmHg) requires careful fluid management to improve renal perfusion and hemodynamic stability prior to contrast administration.
Minimizing contrast volume and using less nephrotoxic contrast agents are crucial for renal safety in hypotensive patients.
Close monitoring of renal function post-contrast is essential to detect early signs of contrast-induced nephropathy.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.

protocol_selection.name: Trauma CT — Chest, Abdomen & Pelvis with Contrast
protocol_selection.description: Contrast CT of torso with trauma-focused reformats; may include delayed images as needed.
protocol_selection.contrast_timing: Portal venous phase, possible delayed imaging to assess hemorrhage.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Standard contrast dose; trauma protocols may include split bolus techniques.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Minimize field-of-view and dose; use alternative imaging if stable and renal risk high.
